definitions.definition: a space or passage inside the entrance or front door of a building
definitions.labels: especially in British EnglishNorth American English also

examples.text: Her brother was standing in the front hall.
She ran into the hall and up the stairs.

preposition: at the end of the hall

definitions.definition: a passage in a building with rooms down either side

examples.text: I headed for Scott's office down the hall.
the room across the hall

preposition: at the end of the hall

definitions.definition: a building or large room for public meetings, meals, concerts, etc.

examples.text: a **concert/sports hall**
a banqueting/conference hall
an exhibition hall
There are three **dining halls** on campus.
the Royal Albert Hall
The next meeting is in the **community hall** on Tuesday.
A jumble sale will be held in the **village hall** on Saturday.
More than 200 members of the public packed the main hall at the community centre.
Our voices echoed round the huge bare hall.
The strains of the national anthem filled the hall.
at dinner in the mess hall
It's important for a concert hall to have good acoustics.
Our stand is located in the main exhibition hall.

definitions.definition: a building for university or college students to live in

examples.text: She's living in hall(s).
Haddon Hall
Berrington Hall was built in the late 18th century.

wordOrigin: Old English hall, heall (originally denoting a roofed space, located centrally, for the communal use of a tribal chief and his people); of Germanic origin and related to German Halle, Dutch hall, also to Norwegian and Swedish hall.
